text: the following report contains some
disturbing images
these are some of the children who made
it off Mount Sinjar many have lost
friends or family all are now homeless
but they're alive and they're happy
about that but for some self
preservation came at a huge cost as the
Yazidi is fled in their thousands
policeman Jalal bothered peso was
struggling he and his wife had with them
three kids too young to walk with
fighters from the Islamic state at their
backs they were forced to make an almost
impossible decision to leave their
four-year-old son Aziz and save the
others there was a hub by the side of
the room we put him in there and left
him we couldn't carry him anymore
he was too heavy it must have been a
very difficult decision to make to leave
one of your children behind as you fled
we just couldn't cope but Kurdish
fighters later found the boy and brought
him to a hospital
inside Kurdish controlled Syria here the
BBC found him badly dehydrated and with
his corneas burnt by the punishing Sun
no one knew his name or who his parents
were
Jalal was eventually alerted by a
relative who saw a picture of the boy on
Facebook he made the journey to Syria
yesterday hoping to be reunited with his
son but he arrived too too late Aziz
died early that morning
we traveled to the frontline of the now
meaningless border between Syria and
Iraq these fighters mostly Syrian Kurds
have been battling is for more than two
years they say they're not intimidated
by the Islamist groups gruesome tactics
but you can see buildings just a few
hundred meters from Jenna and they live
vertical at the Isis runs as a base
these two sides are literally eyeball to
eyeball as we watch the fighters spot
some ice vehicles on the move through
the midday heat they fire off a few
shots just to remind them that we're
here this man tells me the people in
this camp don't even count towards the
figure of three million refugees from
the Syrian war thousands of Iraq's
Yazidis have found temporary refuge here
inside Kurdish controlled Syria but they
don't feel safe and many say they've
already made up their minds to abandoned
their homeland for good
Gabriel gatehouse BBC news in northern
Syria
